We had the most wonderful stay at Walker Hotel. Amazing staff, great room views and fantastic location. Close to the subway and right in the middle of my favorite neighborhood in town.You should really stay here and enjoy its great restaurant, also. You’ll feel at home (or better).

The Walker Hotel is a gem in the heart of Manhattan. Stayed there only 1 night, but the experience was great. Neatly refurbished, this is a very cosy and well-maintained place. I stayed in room 504, very nice, just what I needed, two complementary bottle of water were welcoming me upon entering the room. The style of the hotel is very elegant. Service is great. I did not have the time to sample some of the food in the restaurant, but for what I have seen on the plates of other guests, it looked very good. My room was very quiet and I did not hear the regular sounds of New York, honking cars and police, ambulance or firemen sirens.

We stayed in the pied a terre room with balcony. A real treat. And the hotel is in a great location with easy access to Union Square and the Village. We would definitely stay again, as my wife has declared this her new favorite in NYC.

I booked an entire week at this hotel while in New York for work last week based on a recommendation from a friend who has stayed there many times plus the fact that it is only two blocks away from the office where I work.When I arrived at the hotel, coincidentally at the same time as my friend, I was given a small, dark and very tired looking room on the fourth floor overlooking a construction site. I was told upon check-in that the 'nicer' rooms were all booked for the evening and that they would see if they could move me around later in the week - which was unacceptable given that I had booked the hotel the week before and had planned on staying there for five nights.When I got to my room it was awful -- old and worn decor, a mattress that was barely off of the tired and dirty rug, a tiny bathroom, etc. I called down to the desk and told them that this wasn't what I had either expected or hoped for and that I wouldn't be staying. So I went downstairs, my luggage still unpacked, and checked out. They told me that they understood, and apologized for the inconvenience. I was okay with this ... and I found another hotel nearby that was much nicer and is my new go-to spot in Manhattan.Then, to my surprise, at the end of the week in NYC, I found out that the Walker Hotel billed me for a night and has since refused to back down or credit this back. Unbelievable. I stayed in the room for no more than five minutes before leaving. Never unpacked, never touched the bed, the closet, the bathroom, etc. They told me that I could leave and that there wouldn't be an issue or any charges levied. I asked about this, very clearly. And then, after I left, and with my corporate card in hand, they billed me.Stay away from this hotel ... this is not the way that customers should be treated. Very very unhappy with the service and, quite frankly, being taken advantage of in this way.

My best friend (from when we were 8), her daughter and son-in-law and my daughter decided to meet for a NY weekend as she turned 72. She and I had grown up in New York and had our special spots--one of which was the West Village. After waffling for a month over AirBnBs, we decided on the Walker because 1. It was perfectly located 2. It had great reviews and 3. We really didn't want to cook. I told the reservations desk on the phone (I did not book online or with a 3rd party) that this was a special weekend and they complied with a piece of birthday cake and a candle waiting for us as well as "goodnight cookies." The hotel itself is lovely--small but elegant rooms with INCREDIBLE views of the city and windows that open. Wonderful seating area for morning coffee and late-night entertainment (a trio of young musicians did some jazz and standards as we sat over drinks) and a fitness place downstairs that none of us used. Our only minor complaint is the lack of cabinets and shelves for our stuff, but so what? Absolutely wonderful 2 days... we will be back.

The standard rooms are a tight squeeze (this is Manhattan!), but the service is excellent. The overall vibe is classy yet welcoming. Definitely take advantage of its restaurant, Society Cafe, which offers a relaxed setting and delicious everything.

I got a great deal at this place, or so I thought !The evening before I was due to arrive, I received a voice mail from the hotel , telling me to call them. When I returned the call and spoke to a Travis, he told me that the price I was being charged online was inaccurate, the computer system made a mistake, and the hotel could NOT honor that deal. I was FLABBERGASTED !!! Could not honor the price THEY ADVERTISED? Well, I had never heard of such a thing! He then told me, the price should have been more than $300 per night of what was advertised, but he’d give me a discount of only $150 additional per night... This is ludicrous!!! I clicked to pay one price, but was being forced to pay significantly MORE at the last minute !If their system was to blame, and not I, then they should eat that cost; not call their customers and make them pay more than what was ADVERTISED. This is how business is supposed to be done from reputable companies- and NOT what they did... I told Travis to cancel my reservation, I would not be extorted for more money!!!!! This is a BAD way to do business. SHAME ON YOU WALKER HOTEL! SHAME SHAME SHAME!!!DO NOT BOOK a room at this HOTEL ! Try the Standard Hotel instead!

The Art Deco style is beautiful, down to the rotary dial phone in the room. The lobby, below street level, is cozy and well appointed. The front desk staff were extremely accommodating. The room was comfortable, and we enjoyed the cookies and turndown service. The only things lacking were mirrors in well-lit locations outside the bath and USB ports anywhere in the room. The WiFi was excellent, however. The location is perfect for exploring the village.

After staying with friends in Hells Kitchen, staying at The Walker afforded us the quietest sleep yet. The boutique is in a wonderful location, great restaurant and bar/lounge area providing eager customer service. One night we arrived back to a live jazz singer in the lounge with fire place burning. We enjoyed the craft cocktails, and room service in our room. The subway was nearby which allowed us to save some money on transportation. I would stay here again.

We came to NY to celebrate our anniversary and visit our daughter. I had stayed at the Walker once before and wanted my husband to see it. The rooms are a little small but the location is fantastic--a quiet street within walking distance of many fabulous sites. When the desk staff found out that it was our anniversary, they gave us a room with a great view and some delicious treats from the restaurant. They were friendly and helpful throughout our stay and always called us by name. They were the best hotel staff I've ever had. Kudos to Perry, Liza, Cameron, and Bates.

Conveniently located, nice-looking hotel, but very poor service. Our room was so hot we could not sleep (in winter) and the thermostat did not respond to changes. We called the front desk for help and they said to open a window while they sent someone from engineering. That help never came and the room was too hot the next night as well. In the morning, we asked for coffee to be brought to the room prior to our departure, which also never came, not even by the time we checked out an hour later. The receptionist very helpfully offered to not charge us for the coffee (!!!) for our troubles with the heat. We won't stay here again.

The Walker is somehow on a quiet street in the best location. Walk to everything. The Walker Terrace room is exquisite - I was on 17 with the biggest soaking tub i've ever seen and a terrace overlooking the city. Like being in every great NY movie ever.Staff isn't slick -they actually all engage and care. Great place to be!!!

I recently stayed at the Walker Greenwich Village while visiting my daughter in the city. Location is ideal for walking to many areas on both east and west sides. Cozy lobby and nice bar and restaurant. We had dinner one night and drinks and everything we sampled was very good. Room was tight, as most are in NYC, but I had booked the most basic double. Very clean though and little treats at turndown each night. And shower water pressure was almost TOO much, like a fire hose! Overall, a pleasant stay at lovely, quiet old hotel on a not-too-busy street. Not a good choice for a hip bar scene, but otherwise would recommend.

The location is great, you are right in the middle of the island and about a 10-minute walk to Soho, East/West Village. Having lived in this area for years I wanted to stay near my old apartment at a reasonable price. However, the rooms were slightly worn and shower pressure was so intense and the shower drain was clogged. There were other positives of course, such as a nice lobby and restaurant, valet parking, quiet rooms, and they offered a free drink if you book online with them. I would probably stay again due to the location but overall was a little underwhelmed.

The Walker is a beautiful, chic, boutique hotel in a fabulous Greenwich village neighborhood. The service was wonderful, staff incredible and accommodations just perfect. The beds and pillows were so cushy and comfortable. The whole vibe of the place is cozy and retro. The lobby is very inviting with a great fireplace and some cozy spots to sit and relax. The bar and restaurant are also awesome. A huge plus was the onsite gym, which has two treadmills, an elyptical machine and weights. Every person we encountered was helpful and friendly. The rooms were what we expected in terms of size for NYC, but definitely spacious enough for two people. We had a Bedford double with two full sized beds, as I was traveling with my mom. I poured over reviews and debated over where to stay. After seeing that the Marlton had no gym, and their only room with two beds had only twin sized beds, I decided to try The Walker. Luckiky I did, and now have found my new go-to hotel in NYC. Thanks for a fabulous stay.

We stayed at The Walker Hotel when visiting our daughter in college nearby. It's conveniently located on a beautiful, tree-lined street, is well-appointed, and has solid service. The common areas are cozy, complete with a welcoming lobby fireplace and restaurant. On certain evenings, jazz students from The New School play in the lobby, which is a nice touch. The rooms are also well-appointed, but very cozy, which isn't a problem for us, because we don't spend much time in our room. The bed was comfortable, the TV wasn't too small or far from the bed, and the nightstands were big enough. As is typical of renovated, historic hotels, the rooms are reminiscent of a bygone era, when not much other than a bed was required, hence the lack of storage/closet space, and compact (but nice and clean) bathrooms. The hotel restaurant is fine, but with so much good food around every corner, it usually makes more sense to venture out...though it's nice to know you won't have to, if you'd rather stay at the hotel. Murray's Bagels is on 6th and 13th, and they make a terrific bagel, by the way. You're a stone's throw from anything and everything when staying at this hotel, so if your destination isn't within walking distance, the subway is close by.

A lovely entrance and tiny cozy lobby suggests a good hotel, however having traveled extensively and stayed in many hotels worldwide, their is nothing more disgusting than taking a shower and the basin fills up because it is either clogged or draining slow until your feet are sloshing in water. You cut short your shower and turn off the water before the basin fills and overflows into the bathroom and your room.This coupled with the fact that the hinge on the glass shower door was coming off and the door hit the main glass shower when closed-causing a potentially dangerous situation.I had to leave for meetings each day I stayed there at 6:00AM before the day manger arrived. I complained with the night man and was told it would be taken care of and the manager would be in contact with me after i checked out. The problem was not addressed while I stayed there and it has been several weeks and I have not heard from the hotel.At $350+/night one expects to have better facilities.

We were in town for a family entertainment event. Walker Hotel is so convenient to mass transit and points of interest. But the staff, above all, are superlative, friendly, helpful and engaging. We can't wait to return.

The first thing to catch our eye as we approached the Walker, were the two gas lamps flickering above the doorway. As we entered the main lobby we descended a castle like staircase into a warm welcoming lobby, the focal point, a stone fireplace was surrounded by numerous nooks to retreat to with my sweetheart (after all it was Valentine's Eve). The staff were as friendly and inviting as the decor, always attentive to our needs throughout our stay. After checking in, we continued towards the elevators traveling through a narrow arched brick hallway reminiscent of a 30's speakeasy. The room we stayed in had a balcony with a breathtaking view of the Empire State Building and the surrounding streets. The 30's motif carried over into the room as well. The bathroom featured a glass enclosed shower and separate soaking tub, all the fixtures and bath accessories again reflected the 30's vibe. Everything about our stay was perfect and we will definitely be visiting the Walker again. We also dined in the "in hotel" restaurant, The Society Cafe but that's another review....: )
user_name:
Ghost1917
New York City, New York

review_body: This might be my new favorite hotel. While the room was small, it was elegant, quiet and luxurious. Great shower with lots of hot water and pressure, one of the best beds I've slept on in a hotel, and the room was quiet quiet quiet. The restaurant in the ground floor was good enough that I'd go out of my way to dine there even if I wasn't a hotel guest. We just had a perfect experience.

What a great place to stay in NYC! Charming hotel, attentive staff and a great location make the Walker Hotel a unique destination. From the moment we arrived til we left, the staff was accommodating -- helpful with room selection at check in, late night ice delivery with a smile and overflow dining the the reception area due to a booked restaurant made our stay delightful.

Quaint hotel in perfect spot. Quiet, clean, and comfortable. The staff is very friendly and attentive. Hotel has a great little rest and bar. Would definitely stay here again and recommend to friends and family
user_name:
Kelly S
Park City, Utah, United States

review_body: Great location and wonderful staff. Stylish space and ideal for my business trip. Really enjoyed the complimentary water and evening homemade biscuits but the only thing missing was a fridge to keep drinks cool.

The ideal location. Greenwich Village has so much to offer with a variety of great bars and restaurants within walking distance from the hotel. The staff were very helpful, in particular Steven, who was fantastic to deal with. Great service at the hotel bar and restaurant which made it a perfect meeting spot for friends to get together before exploring what the amazing City has to offer! I’d recommend staying at this hotel to anyone visiting NYC!

For boutique hotel lovers, this is a great find in a fantastic district of New York. I stayed at the hotel for a week and whilst there are many positives, there are also some drawbacks, which left me with a slightly mixed view of the hotel. On the positive, the decor is appealing and a lot of effort has gone into ensuring all aspects of the hotel are aligned in art deco style. All the way from the entrance, restaurant, lifts and rooms with lovely rotary telephones. Even the gym is decked out in very charming style. The rooms are on the small side, however, definitely not the smallest I've encountered in New York. Whilst the bed was comfortable, the bedding is very light, and I found the room very cold, however, the heating was incredibly loud, so it was hard to sleep with that running. I also found whilst the rooms had good sound-proof between rooms, it's very noisy if someone is knocking on the room next door, which unfortunately seemed to happen at late and early hours for my neighbours! One of the very nice touches of the hotel was returning to find different home-baked style cookies in the room after turndown, which is a lovely touch. I also had room service delivered from the restaurant on a number of occasions, and there was a really nice menu available, the food was delicious and the service was friendly, professional and prompt. I found the breakfast selection a little limited, however, the restaurant is a nice spot to sit and start the day. I did find the bar experience disappointing, I was joined by friends and the bar area itself was very busy, and so we were directed to the lobby as we weren't eating, so weren't able to sit at the tables, although at the time it appeared rather empty. However, the service was very slow and quite disinterested. I then asked to put the bill on my room and was told that was not possible, however, once I flagged that this was very inconvenient, I was told they would sort something out. i also used the gym, which was small but very well equipped for a quick workout with nice running machines, weights and mats etc which was all clean and in good order. Overall it's hard to find a great hotel in New York. I think this one is getting there with some minor changes.

Incredible location: almost next to New School and Union Square, this place is just minutes walk from anything downtown, be it East Village, West Village, Former meat packing district now fancy neighborhood around new Whitney Museum building. Rooms are simple, but elegant and very clean, everything what you need, including bathrob and slippers, plus authentic village view from your window (get room on 11 and above!). Absolutely wonderful staff at the front desk, especially Leo: kind and attentive service which you’ll never get at the big chain overpriced hotels. Lovely small restaurant and bar on the premises.

We stayed at the Walker during my daughter's first college audition. It was such an amazing visit! The place is so charming and clean. The fireplace in the lounge was totally welcoming. The staff is really pleasant and helpful! The nightly sweets and 2 drink vouchers were such a treat! The Society Cafe on site had delicious food and was quite convenient if we didn't feel like going out to grab a bite to eat. We loved our time so much that we're staying there again when we come back for her next audition!

helpful staff - nice rooms some a little small but we upgraded to a larger one which was good for New York - good food - welcoming bar - would return to this boutique hotel - it was very easy to order a taxi at the front desk -

We loved staying here. The entrance, lobby and bar area are so warm and inviting - different than the big hotel chains. Our room was small but cozy, great water pressure and a comfy bed. It did get a bit noisy in the hallways on the weekend but that was our only complaint. Loved being able to get a nice latte in a real mug downstairs every morning to bring up to our room! Met friends at the hotel bar one night for a drink. Staff was friendly and accommodating. Would definitely recommend.

This is a beautiful art deco boutique hotel, however design has taken priority over a functional layout and comfort for the guests.The good1. Very helpful and knowledgeable staff2. Foyer and lounge area very cozy and inviting3. Good restaurant (breakfast)4. Very comfortable bed5. Good showerThe bad 1.The standard room size is tiny, not enough room for two people with suitcases.2. Wardrobes too small for two people - why front hanging??3. Bedside tables, no space to put any items on them.4. Why no fridge in the room?5. Expensive Tivoli Clock Radio which did not work and is located too far away from the bedside table and not visible6. Central air conditioning system which cannot be adjusted and turns the room into a sauna! Solution from reception was to open a window!7. No coffee and tea making facilities! Customers expect this in a budget hotel!!8. Very expensive drinks at the bar!9. Bathroom sink in room only a trickle of cold water and took ten minutes to drain

We chose this hotel because of it's location and website appeal. We were in NYC for 7 nights over Christmas.The standard room we initially booked, was cramped and lacked wardrobe and shower room space. We requested an upgrade, which cost us an extra 60 dollars per night. While it was much more spacious, the wardrobe and shower room were still cramped. There was no fridge in the room or tea/coffee making facilites either. Breakfast on our first morning was a disaster. The Society Cafe restaurant was not busy, yet the service was snail paced. Eventually my wife and I ordered eggs benedict each. After a considerable wait, one plate of eggs benedict arrived with two plates, eggs benedict to share! To compound it, the food was cold, so we sent it back. We did not return to the restaurant again.The other big problem was slamming doors in the corridor. No matter how gently we tried, our bedroom door, along with every other, just slammed shut. They should go to a Premier Inn in the UK and learn how it is done - silently. All this was a pity really because the hotel had a great atmosphere and the reception staff were tip-top. The hotel has all the ingredients of a great place to stay, but is in need of a bit of modernisation.

Lovely welcome, nice bar area and lovely rooms. The hotel is boutique nice bathroom, good bedding and tv. The reception area had a lovely fire and a good place to rest, whilst out the front of the hotel, whilst quiet was only a few minutes to lots of places to eat and drink

Warm and welcoming Art Deco Boutique Hotel in a brilliant location. Staff couldn't have been more friendly and helpful. We loved the lobby area with sofas, fire and occasional live music. Room was pretty but small and air conditioning noisy - but I would still thoroughly recommend this hotel to travellersThank you

Stayed for 3 nights in December with a friend in a twin room, and it was on the top floor. The view was incredible, all the way downtown and could clearly see OWO.What I liked - the lobby of the hotel and its Art Deco design, the location is great and it was very easy to get around Manhattan between walking and the close location of the subway. The petit-fours delivered by housekeeping in the afternoon were a nice touch. The view from our room was great to wake up and the sunsets were incredible.What I didn’t like - the NOISE. Wow. I’ve stayed in a lot of hotels, but the noise in this hotel is worst I’ve ever experienced. I thought my bed was right next to pipes or that I was sleeping in the elevator itself with all the clanging through the night. We were high enough up to not hear the street noise, this was purely internal. The beds were also lumpy and way too soft to the point of making it uncomfortable to sleep. The heavy shower handle fell off one morning and narrowly missed my foot. There is no fridge in the room (yes I’m sure it says that in the available room facilities, but it was still frustrating to not be able to store things for breakfast or snacks).But the worst thing of all, was when I asked front desk for advice on getting to JFK airport, they said to allow 30-45 mins for getting there in a cab. Thank god I added in 45 minutes contingency on that 45 minutes, as we made our check-in with 7 minutes to spare when there was traffic en route to JFK. Overall, the great location and wasn’t enough to cover the general disappointment of the stay, and you can definitely find similar, better value hotels on Manhattan.

We spent the weekend here. My husband had to Union Square for business and I tagged along. The hotel is chic and boutique. You enter and walk into the lobby which is cozy and inviting. There is a fireplace, several places to sit and actual books on the shelf. We stayed in a queen room on the 14th floor street side. The room was small and functional. Although the bed was a little soft for my liking, I got a good night's sleep every night. We opened the window for some fresh air for sleeping. Fresh cookies everynight for turndown service. This hotel is very close to my husband's office. He will be staying here when in on business.

The lobby is so warm and inviting and our room was very comfortable. We have stayed before and thoroughly enjoy the hotel. It is convenient to what we want to do and our family lives a block and a half away. My only negative is environmently friendly lighting is not quite enough light for me. We plan to stay again soon.

The front desk staff is very friendly and helpful and the hotel was beautifully decorated for the Christmas holiday. Our room was lovely and wonderfully quiet and the hotel is very conveniently located. However, there are two things that could be improved upon....the lighting (it's quite soft which I love, but if you really need to see something, there's no option to turn up the lights) and the housekeeping staff. The carpet was not vacuumed despite the fact that some leaves and debris had blown in when we opened the patio door. The soap dish wasn't cleaned even though it was covered in melted soap and we were only given one clean bath towel for the two of us. Despite these things, we did enjoy our stay and will return next December when we spend Christmas with our NYC family.

Over the years, I have stayed in more than 40 hotels in Manhattan ranging from the very posh to mid-range generic business hotels. Nowadays, everyone in the "hospitality business" wants to please their clients and convert them into regular customers. Our initial experience with the Walker was very good albeit brief (one night cut even shorter by spending much of it with a friend's trip to an Emergency Room).All of the hotel staff we met (front desk, restaurant, service) were cheerful, kind and personable. In conversation, they were focused on making their guests welcome. We had a brunch and a breakfast at the hotel. The ambiance of the room and the quality and variety of the menu evidenced a desire and success in rising above an average and forgettable hotel eatery.The lobby of the hotel is charming, with plenty of inviting nooks and crannies where you can relax and have a civilized conversation. Our room was small but clean, quiet and with a bit of art deco personality. The neighborhood is distinctive and convenient, more residential and interesting than mid-town. It is a good vantage point for exploring the city, and I speak as someone who grew up in Brooklyn and Manhattan. While we have yet to adopt one hotel in NYC as our own (as we have done in Paris, Dublin and a number of other cities), we would definitely return to the Walker. It is congenial and a good value.

Woke up in the middle of the night to a sauna- had set the room to 65 and it was at 80 degrees. The front desk told me to open a window- great, because I want to hear and smell the streets of New York as I sleep. The next morning, I go to take a shower and it’s lukewarm at best. I tell the front desk and again it’s “we’ll look into it” no “I’m so sorry, we’ll take care of that right now.” I leave the hotel for 5 hours, come back before dinner and no one has cleaned my room. I tell the front desk and again it’s “okay.” No apologies or anything. Day 2: go to take a shower and it’s even colder than the day before.Made a trip advisor account just to warn others. Decor is cute, but I will never be back

The Walker has a friendly staff in a great location but fell short on just about everything else. The room was 80 degrees and they told us the ac doesn’t work when it’s under 55 degrees outside (it was 65 that day) so the solution was to open the window and let it cool that way. But then overnight it would freeze so we woke up cold. Second there was no hot water in the shower. When asked to remedy, they had no solution. Finally, they did not clean our room unless specifically asked. We will not stay here again and others beware.

My wife and I stayed at the Walker for 4 days just before the Christmas Holidays. We had a Grove Queen room facing 13th Street on the 10th floor. The great things about the Walker are (1) its staff (everyone we met had a quick smile and wanted to help), (2) a clean room, (3) a quiet room (13th is not a heavily traveled street), (4) comfortable bed, (5) a very good location for us (daughter lives a few blocks north), (6) our a la carte breakfast was well prepared, quickly delivered, and tasty, and (7) easy access to the Holland Tunnel (think about flying to Newark). Comments are (a) the room, being cozy, was smaller than expected (daughter said that this was typical in NYC) with no coffee maker, fridge or chest to store clothes (other than a small armoire for hanging a few), and limited space to open suitcases (it did, however, have a small desk and a safe), (b) get an Uber app since taxis are scarce on the street - our Ubers came within 2 - 3 minutes (taxis are more available 1/2 block (long block) east or west on major N/S Avenues). We'll go again to the Walker, but, depending on the length of stay, will consider getting a larger room (at a higher price).

First night noticed a stain on the sheet, called desk, a guy came and handed me the sheets and turned to leave, I said “you want ME to change the sheets???” He said he would do it.Next morning , noticed the down comforter had a stain, told them we were going out for the day and I would leave it visible(size of a golf ball) ...came back bed was made with the same stained comforter. The only redeeming factor was it was a good location. I will not be returning to this hotel..there’s way too much competition in the city to be off your game!

I enjoyed the location of the Walker Hotel, and the intimate boutique feeling it offers. The staff at the front desk were very accommodating. The room, Grove Queen, was small but clean, comfortable and had a nice view of the Empire State Building. The water pressure in the shower was great. I was disappointed there was no fridge in the room. Though the biggest disappointment was the service in the lounge (lobby). On 2 separate occasions, the server completely forgot our order. We watched as other guests were seated and served, finally having to remind her that we had ordered drinks. As we were finishing our drinks we noticed a cockroach on the floor. Overall, I expected a much better experience for this price point.

Great Hotel, perfect location, near to tube station, very helpful staff, room was comfortable, the only thing I would have liked was tea and coffee making facilities, but wouldn’t put me of going again, and New York was amazing.

We stayed at the Walker hotel in Greenwich Village primarily for the location, but if we were to go back to New York, we would stay in the Walker hotel because of the excellent service they offer. We had booked a room for two nights and then went for two nights to Washington before booking another two nights back at the Walker hotel. The staff immediately offered to keep our heavy suitcases in storage until we returned and better than that, they sorted our hotel in Washington that had been unexpectedly cancelled. We were in a bit of a panic with no hotel booked, but Marcus,(manager or front desk manager, I can't remember, sorry Marcus) immediately got on the phone to sort us out. To make the horror of having our booking cancelled go away, he also offered us complimentary drinks in the bar and upon our return two nights later, upgraded us to a room with a fabulous view of the NY skyline. Everyone at the hotel was extremely curteuous, Liza, Perry, Keith were very accomodating and friendly. We really felt at home in the hotel. The rooms are small, but the beds are very comfortable with nice sheets, while the bathrobes were so nice, I wanted to take them home. I appreciated that they had proper hair dryers and not the kind that are fixed to the wall and where you have to hold your finger on the power button the whole time. They also provided us with umbrellas when it rained. The rooms have good windows that keep the noise out and can even be opened a little, which is not that common in high rise building. It was a really lovely experience and we highly recommend the hotel for anyone looking to spend time in NY. Thank you again for your hospitality.

Nice hotel excellent staff I had a wonderful stay the à la carte breakfast was awesome it's obveous that we have to choose only one item for the prefix rate the room was clean and the bathroom as well with all the products that come with it!!

Had a truly amazing stay at the Walker Hotel Greenwich for a variety of reasons~First of all a huge thank you to everyone who was at the front desk and put up with me. I was stunned by how friendly and willing to help everyone was because I definitely had a billion random questions and demands. Secondly, the art-deco and Gatsby- esque vibes made the entire property entirely unique. The rooms are peppered with vintage telephones and radios, and it is truly an experience you're unlikely to find anywhere else. In addition, I was pleasantly surprised with cookies and a name-card at in my room; it's evident that the hotel cares about it's guests!Also be sure to try Society Cafe! The chef is amazing and the menu has everything from comfort foods reimagined to unique twists on flavors from around the world~ Thumbs up to everyone at the hotel, especially the front office staff and the MarcAnthony, for making our short stay so memorable!

Expensive hotel for an average service.Very small double bed rooms and poor cleanliness. Room view was on the disgusting backyard, but calm fortunately.Very noisy restaurant at underground level with no outside view to the street.Taxi services not very efficient.

My partner and I stayed for 4 nights at The Walker Hotel. First impressions it is really pretty, decorated in Art Deco style and is cozy, warm and inviting. We stayed in a Grove room which was also nice, a bit chilly and hard to get warm (with a loud air conditioning unit). It is quite small but it was fine for us when we were out and about all day. I’d imagine if you like a lot of space this isn’t for you. We had to squish past each other to get ready everyday. They didn’t have tea or coffee facilities in the room, which I really missed.The restaurant looked nice, we didn’t actually eat there though.It was easy to get to the subway from the Hotel and was in walking distance to nice bars and restaurants and shops. The only real negative I would say was I found the staff a bit unhelpful. A few were nice but on our first night we asked where the nearest subway was and we got a blank look and a “just a round the corner”...and that was all the information we got. It was our first time in NYC and we thought from hotel staff it was just a bit strange they weren’t more helpful. Or there could have been some information in the room. Anyway we just resorted to google maps instead of asking anything.Overall a small but nice hotel.

This was our first visit to the Walker, The first night was challenging, as I had reserved a room on the lower floors. I spoke with the manager, Samantha, and she said would try to get a room switch the following day. The next morning Travis approved a major upgrade and put us on the top floor facing the Empire State building. It was an amazing room and view. The art-deco decor was very charming and fun. For the next four days the staff could not have been more polite, cheerful, helpful and efficient: Joyce, Bates and Perry insured that we had the visit that we had hoped for. The restaurant and staff had amazing food at very reasonable prices. Their farm to table ingredients made for some wonderful dishes. The location was a block from the L and B,D,F subway lines for very quick travel. We will be coming back to the Walker for our next NYC visit.

great location, lovely food and atmosphere in the hotel. Nice comfy rooms. Just perfect for a stay in NYC - will stay again for sure - no questions! High quality property, attentive staff and in a nice quiet street that still gives super easy access to the city.

I spent only one night here, but I enjoyed it. The Walker has a great location in greenwich Village, very near Chelsea. It's a small-ish but elegant boutique hotel with great character and charm.I found it through my StashAwards account - it's not formally part of the Stash Awards system, but I was able to earn Stash points there. Stash then pushes the rez through booking.com, which was a very easy and smooth process.This is not the cheapest hotel in New York, but nor is it the most expensive. I would estimate it to be pretty much down the middle. The only availability (last minute booking) was a Grove Queen room. The room was small, but that's to be expected in older hotels like this. It was well-decorated in what I would call modern deco. My only specific "complaints" are that the bed was too low (though that's irrelevant once you are lying down), and I couldn't stand at the bathroom sink with the door bathroom door open as it was such a tight space.Nonetheless, I enjoyed my stay there, and would readily consider staying again. The ambience is cozy yet elegant, and the staff were professional an courteous throughout.This was a great find that I hope to visit again some day!

Staff excellent - moved us from a tiny room which could hardly hold our two suitcases , to a much larger one as we were staying 4 nights.Comfortable and the feeling of a small personal hotel. Location good and easy to get to subway (14th st) which got us around upper Manhattan/ Cebtral park and downtown. Greenwich village closeby

I have stayed here twice now and each time I have been very happy with my experience. When I come back again to visit my granddaughter in college, I will stay here again. Like an old and charming friend, I look forward to my next visit. Although it is hard to explain the charm, I can say that it is a warm and inviting atmosphere and all aspects of the environment have been well thought out and well chosen. The staff is always more than helpful. All is good here.

We spent 3 nights at the Walker during Thanksgiving week. It was very busy but the staff could not have been more accommodating, helpful, friendly and efficient. We had a lovely time and felt very comfortable.

Our room was in kinda gothic/steam-punk style - pretty cool.It was also very spacious. The only problem - there was only one small desk, even though there was a lot of space for another desk or table that would be really nice.

I travel to NY for work frequently, and stay mostly boutique hotels and occasionally Hyatt and Marriot properties, programs in which I have elite status. On this trip however, our mission was to take kids to see Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. We wanted to pick a cozier, neighborhood hotel.I was underwhelmed with the room size, which I would describe as perhaps the smallest I’ve ever had in NYC- and I’ve been staying in hotels primarily in Manhattan (and some in Brooklyn) for over 20 years. It was a 250 dollar room at best, certainly not 300+. Our shower door in the bathroom had a broken hinge, which prevented it from closing properly, and the bathroom ceiling needed to be repainted. The air conditioning and heating seems to run pretty constantly, without every impacting the room temperature. TV in the room was quite small- maybe 32-35 inches? Nit-picking aside, we had a situation the morning we were checking out, where one of the kids got sick in the room. I called down to get some help, or cleaning supplies, or extra towels, etc. now- obviously this is not pleasant, but as a parent you get pretty blasé about cleaning up stuff like this, which I did. What I found really disappointing was the time it took to get anyone to show up and drop of towels, or offer any help at all. Eventually, about two hours later, and after several calls down to the front desk- someone came up and dropped off some towels. 3-4 hours later, housekeeping came up to the room and kind of tried to help- but didn’t actually do anything other than ask what had happened. (Usually in these situations, you spray down the carpet with some cleaning products, vacuum, etc)On top of that- I had left an extra tip in the room for housekeeping, on top of what I leave usually, but realized when we were at the airport that I had left a 150 dollar set of Bluetooth headphones in the room. I called the front desk 2-3 times over the next several hours trying to see if housekeeping had found them or if someone could check the room. Despite the front desk staff promising that they would call me back, they never did. It’s a fact that cleaning staff sometimes grab stuff in the rooms, but that’s usually why you send someone up to the room to check for stuff before it’s cleaned. The fact that the staff didn’t seem to really care, or make any effort, is really what dropped this review to 2 stars. Also worth mentioning that the staff handed us a card upon leaving asking for a favorable review on TripAdvisor, so they seem to have their influence/social media campaign on point. Ironically, that prompted me to leave this. Every business has off days- but the housekeeping issues and stolen/lost item happened on the day we were leaving and really was the nail in the coffin. There are hundres of hotels in which one could find larger rooms with more up to date amenities and better service. I’m sure someone from the stafff will immediately leave a throughtful, elegantly worded response just below this review, but I really needed the help when I was there, and I hope someone on the housekeeping staff enjoy their new headphones.

The staff at the Walker are very accommodating and helpful! Every request (small or large) is treated with importance and they had great suggestions for a fun evening out. Nice boutique type hotel....

The staff at the Walker are beyond accommodation, helpful, and prompt! Every request (small or large) is treated with importance. The rooms are in art-deco in style, with luxurious bathroom products by C.O. Bigelow. The rooms are small, and the do not offer a two queen bed room option, which is my group's typical room option while traveling. However, the quality bed linens and comfortable mattresses made the smaller sleeping accommodations doable. If you are like me and my friends, Times Square is the last place you want to stay, then definitively check out the Walker Hotel in Greenwich.

Nice boutique hotel with awesome bar and lounge area. Location is perfect in Greenwich Village. Very friendly staff. Complementary waters in the room. Only thing that would make it nicer would be complementary or self service coffee in the lounge/lobby as there are no in-room coffee makers

The Walker Hotel is a wonderfully charming and warm Art Deco hotel. Very nice location right in Greenwich Village. The staff is very courteous and professional. The restaurant is very good and the service was excellent.  I would highly recommend it!

Walker Hotel is a trip back to a time when hotels took care of their guests and their needs. The rooms are small but who spends much time in a hotel room on a visit to the city that never sleeps? The restaurant however was not as stellar. Like many places, their staff were more interested in chatting and cell phones then their guests. The food is far over priced. I would stay here again but pass on the restaurant.

Staying at the Walker Hotel was a great experience...not just the location so close to Union Square with it’s many travel options, but the very special attention given by the friendly staff. Nothing was too much trouble from both reception and restaurant staff - they made our stay a memorable friendly experience in a big busy city. My only complaint was that the room was a little dark and could have been improved with more lighting options.

I stayed here recently. The room was small but cozy and the bathroom was rather nice...needs a bit more counter space, though. The restaurant was a bit disappointing....very limited menu and the wait staff were either unstaffed and/or undertrained. The people at the front desk were terrific... courteous and efficient. I would stay here, again if I could get a better rate but I doubt that I'd eat at the restaurant or get a cocktail at the tiny bar.
user_name:
Rebecca B
Forked River, New Jersey

review_body: I’ve stayed at the Walker Hotel a few times. The last time was October 12th during a quick weekend trip to the city. The Dream Team is always very friendly and there is always such a great vibe – when I check in I know I am going to have a great stay. The lobby area has nice cozy chairs and couches. I’ve ordered a drink and appetizers from their restaurant, Society Café, and just relaxed in the lobby while listening to some live piano music. I think the live music may only be on the weekends. The rooms have a beautiful art deco style. The rooms are clean, beds are comfortable, and the linens are great. The shower has good pressure and they provide nice toiletries. The hotel is a hidden gem in Greenwich. It’s close to the subway, and walking distance to shopping and great restaurants. If you don’t feel like leaving the hotel their restaurant has a great brunch/lunch and dinner. I always look forward to coming back!

Danny, Anna, Keith,Irvin and Michael all were excellent at their job. They made me feel welcome. Room was clean and great lighting in the bathroom. Would absolutely stay there again. Great neighborhood, restaurants and shopping.IG

While the room looked a lot more spacious/well kept in the pictures, the "real life" rendition was sub-par. A broken shower door, dirty towels, sheets with holes, two "full" (twin) beds, a disturbingly loud heating system, an abrasive front desk & room service experience are a few of the things that made this stay particularly unpleasant. All things that were particularly frustrating given the price per room per night - 5 days not well spent.

Came for a trip with my mom to celebrate her birthday. The walker hotel was so accommodating and everyone is so friendly! Leo, Liza, and Marcus are the best! Beautiful spot to stay in New York! Highly recommend!

The Walker, besides being perfectly located for our specific needs, was a terrific decision for us. We loved the vibe, the staff (particularly Leo, but also Stephen, Anna, Angel and Danny were all very friendly and helpful!), the bar and the restaurant, but our room was the best part! Clean, with a very comfy bed and operable windows that allowed us to enjoy the sounds of the city (being from Austin that is something we don't get to hear). The bath room was well designed and just, in general, we felt right at home. We highly recommend The Walker! Thanks for a great trip!

- Exceptionally friendly and helpful staff (especially Liza, Anna, Angel, & Danny)- Very clean room- Great location, proximate to many restaurants, the subway, and most importantly, to my son!- Only a 50-block walk from Central Park (I did that, of course!) or a short subway ride

I really liked the vibe at The Walker Hotel, and the location can't be beat if you want to explore the Village. However, I made my reservation way back in July, so I would have expected a better room location. Instead, we were right outside the elevators on the fourth floor, at the back of the hotel. Next time, I'll ask for a room in the front, on a higher floor.

A wonderfully relaxing - albeit brief, one night stay at Walker Hotel in Greenwich Village. I had never been here before nor heard of the hotel, and I was so happy to have stayed here. It's got an amazing vibe with a lovely lounge lobby as you descend the entrance steps. And that vibe carries through to the restaurant in the back and the entire stay.Fantastic staff - Steven (great guy that I first met at the front desk upon entry), Leo (bellman), Aida and Emily (who were there to help with my dinner experience). Also, Liza (front desk), Danny and Keith. Wonderful people who do their best to make the stay easy.

Currently staying at this hotel and it is fantastic! We had such a warm welcome from Perry at the front desk and our room is perfect with a view of the empire state building. Special mentions to Perry for his advice, recommendations, warm greeting and professional manner. Also Eddie with the inside word on attractions. We are planning our return to WH already.

Very good location and nicely appointed rooms. We really like the lobby area with its couches, fireplace and table for happy hour. It was a little strange that their happy hour started at 5:00 pm. I realize this is probably for local residents, but when you’re on vacation, it’s nice to be able to have a glass of wine at 4:00 pm and not have to pay $15-$18/glass. Ada, an assistant manager, made it right but they may want to consider something to better accommodate people staying at the hotel.

From when my wife and I first arrived at the Walker, to the day we left the staff could not have done more for us, thanks Danny, Anna, Liza and Keith. The hotel is stunning, as you walk down the front stairs your are presented with a beautiful lounge area in the foyer with a fireplace and plenty of seating, where you can enjoy a quiet drink or the occasional jazz musician in the evening. We stayed in the Hudson Queen room, which has a private the terrace, which was amazing to soak up the NYC atmosphere each evening. The location is also perfect, with beautiful restaurants and cafes in the immediate area.Thanks again Walker, we will be meeting again soon.

This is my third time at The Walker this year. Incredible location - great restaurants, coffee shops, and The Strand Bookshop all within easy walking distance. Special shout out to Steven for making my stay even more special with his care and attention, as well as suggesting a reservation for their Saturday night live jazz. Highly recommended for stays that are either for business or pleasure.

Booked 3 days thought that I was staying in a luxury hotel. Upon my arrival at midnight, I saw the concave mattress and smelled a moldy smell, so I complained and they upgraded me to the suite, which was basically the same in a higher floor. That same night I asked them to cancel the rest of my reservation and that I was checking out. I ended up going to the Mondrian on Park Ave, which was cheaper and by far better. I would not stay here again an specially after they charged me $430 for one night!

This hotel has such charm and character, the staff is so genuinely friendly and sweet... we will DEFINITELY be staying there again. Anna, Danny, Angel, Leo, and especially Steven (who helped co-ordinate lots of fun surprises with my boyfriend for me on my birthday weekend) were all amazing people who made our stay very comfortable, warm and easy. The rooms are gorgeous and impeccably clean. So much charm!Thanks everyone! Joanne and Joe

Friends of my wife spoke positive of this hotel so we decided to book it to celebrate her birthday and it did not disappoint. The rooms are standard for nyc but the highlights were the neighborhood restaurants and the wine and fruit the hotel gave us. A big thanks to Leo at the front desk and the manager Steven for helping with everything, he had a genuine energy from the first day we arrived and did more than I expected to help set up the plans I had for my wife with emailing us recommendations and introducing us at the bar to the restaurant manger,everyone greeted us everywhere and that felt great.

As one of the last hotels available on Hotel Tonight, I was very pleasantly surprised by this hotel - it was clean, quaint (but with good size rooms) and amazing room service from Society Cafe (the in-house restaurant), which arrived in 10 mins! The staff all around were terrific (as were the Shishito peppers!!!)

I thoroughly enjoyed my stay at The Walker. The customer service is amazing. Leo and Liza really helped me out. Clean room, delicious cookies each night, restocked water and toiletries each day.Thanks
user_name:
Tomeka301
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: I stayed for a few nights on business. Rooms are Art Deco for style and my overall experience was average. Room was on the smaller side and bed was lumpy. There’s a 2 inch gap for the bottom of the door so I could hear everything in the hallway. Why do they have a huge gap?Subway is a 5 minute walk and the hotel is in a safe area, with an artsy movie house next door. The Italian restaurant across the street was fantastic. There are too many nyc hotels that are better for the $.

It was so nice to stay right in the West Village, just around the corner from my family! While convenience was a factor, this is a beautiful hotel in an older building with many luxurious touches and an awesome and helpful staff. We had also had brunch in the Society Cafe which was excellent. Coffee service in the room or in the lobby in the morning would be appreciated though.

Our experience at the Walker was wonderful. We enjoyed the location and the service was professional and sincere. We had to leave a night early due to a family emergency and the staff graciously refunded us the last night stay. The interior was lovely and inviting. This will be our regular hotel as we come to the city often. We especially loved the cookies on our pillows at night! Worth every penny!

Walker Hotel is truly a hidden gem in this bustling city. The architecture and design from the exterior to the guest rooms are postcard worthy. My personal favorite is the Waverly Queen room which is spacious and has a beautiful view of West Village. The water pressure in the shower is also amazing!! The housekeeping team does a superb job at making sure the property is spotless. Thank you Anastasia and Vanessa! This hotel will forever be a personal favorite of mine because of the staff here. Everyone I encountered was personable, thoughtful and warm. They made sure I was welcomed and taken care of throughout my entire stay. A huge thank you to Mac, Marcus, Irvin, Natalia, Perry, Liza, Anna, Danny, Angel and Keith. Hands down, the best hotel staff in all of NYC. While you're here, make sure you stop by Society Cafe. Chef Zabita and his team are constantly pushing out mouthwatering dishes made with the freshest ingredients. If you're coming here for Brunch, the pancakes are a must. If you're coming here for dinner, you have to try the octopus, the steak or any of the pasta dishes. I cannot wait to stay here again. Thank you, Walker family for such a memorable stay!!
user_name:
nantzbk
New York City, New York

review_body: This is not a perfect hotel but it is pretty damn good. The air con fans blow pretty hard, there is no coffee making facilities in the room, very little storage and queen beds, no where to hang towels in the bathroom etc.But the building is spectacular, the lobby and bar restaurant lovely and very atmospheric. The staff are generally good and work hard to make the stay enjoyable.The location is the real benefit for me. One of the few decent hotels in the village and can walk to bleecker st etc easily. The hotel also has great access to subway and isn’t far off the main roads etc.

We've been to NYC many times and found that the Walker provides cleanliness, quiet and superb service! Our rooms were close to the elevator which was not a problem. No need to ever stay in the craziness of midtown again!

The excellent service, the excellent food, and the excellent room were not worth it if I had to sleep with ear plugs,The noise from the elevator is unreasonable and not in a hotel of this kind.It's a shame that this is how the problem is treated, and especially that the staff knows this.I hope you will find a solution.

I am visiting New York on business and had a number of meetings around Greenwich Village so wanted to stay within that area. To my great pleasure I discovered Walkers Hotel. It is an absolute gem tucked away in the heart of the village. Despite being so central it is very quiet and although it has over 100 rooms they are spread over 18 floors and makes the stay feel more like a small boutique experience.The decor is totally fabulous and embraces true Art Deco throughout. I am here on business but would definitely consider this a super, enjoyable and romantic venue to which I would happily return with my wife. The service is excellent. From the time that I checked in I have only had the best experiences with the staff. All are very helpful and professional. The breakfast team are marvellous. I just enjoyed an excellent avocado on toast with poached egg and bacon on the side. It was well prepared and substantial.This is an excellent hotel and even if my next trip to New York is not so village focussed I will stay here and commute to wherever I need to be.

Anna was very helpful and friendly throughout our stay. This is a lovely and quiet place to stay and still be close to restaurants and shopping - actually to all that New York City has to offer.We spent two nights here and travelled into NYC for the finals of the U.S. Open. This was a great choice for us for accomodations.

We stayed here for five nights while visiting New York and attending the US Open Tennis at Flushing Meadows. An easy, one hour subway trip out to Flushing while at the same time staying on Manhattan. Location is great for walking the sights of NYC, we chose to do a lot of walking and covered about 45 kilometres in two days. Lots of good restaurants nearby, including Chelsea Market a few blocks away. Came home later in the evening most nights and felt completely safe. Our room was clean and tidy and was very quiet on the 11th floor, slept great. Francis at the front desk was very helpful when we checked in. Would recommend and stay here again.

I am so pleased that my friend recommended The Walker as a lovely boutique hotel. We enjoyed our stay and will certainly return. The staff was helpful and friendly and we felt cared for. Our room was lovely and the location was perfect for us.

I have stayed at the Walker Hotel four times now and can confirm consistency in these respects: 1) Friendly and professional staff throughout hotel (Anna, Marcus, Perry, Angel and Keith are top notch) 2) Beautiful decor in the rooms, lobby and lounge areas 3) Rooms have solid, quality furniture, quality linens and toiletriesAlmost wish it would stay a hidden gem so I can return anytime! ;-)

The Walker is my go-to place in the city. Its small, intimate atmosphere is big on comfort and convenience.Great food, attentive service and within walking distance to many neighborhood restaurants and cafes. I wouldn't stay anywhere else.

My husband and I stayed at the Walker to celebrate my birthday with friends. What a beautiful boutique hotel! The staff was phenomenal! Anna, Liza, Abner, Marc...all fabulous! The suite we stayed in was small but so well appointed. The birthday surprises provided by the hotel that were in the room upon check-in were such a treat! The hotel bar was so quaint and the drinks were awesome! Room service was fabulous too! Only complaint is the room was a little too warm. Overall...4.5 stars! Highly recommend!

We stayed 3 nights and paid a bit more to have a room on a high floor (16th) with a view. This really felt worth it, since we were having a getaway kind of weekend trip and wanted to feel a little pampered. The room was not big, but certainly not too small by any means. The bathroom was a bit cozy, sure, but that's to be expected in the city. The bed was super comfortable and we slept really well. The shower had excellent water pressure and ample hot water without a wait. We liked the amenities (iron/ironing board, hair dryer, robes, slippers...) as well as the Gatsby-esque theming to the decor complete with antique-style rotary phone. We ordered drinks in the bar downstairs during happy hour on our first night and got a pot of coffee from room service. Staff were accommodating, friendly, and attentive. This place overall felt like a little refuge from the hussle and bussle while being in a cool neighborhood with lots of parks and restaurants within walking distance.

We were just in town over night. A lovely little room with a nice bathroom. We were not there long enough to enjoy the bar. The staff was extremely helpful! Would stay here again! Perfect walking distance to where we needed to be and easy access to the subway.
user_name:
Chris S
Dublin, Ohio, United States

review_body: The Walker Hotel is the perfect place for a getaway, with wonderful amenities and Art Deco glam. It is perfectly located, away from crazy crowds but close to all the great things that Greenwich Village has to offer. Staff is incredibly friendly and helpful. This will be my go-to place when I visit family or go to NYC for shows and shopping.
user_name:
tmterm
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: This is a very interesting hotel in a great location. The rooms are small, but well designed and spotless. There is a great bar and restaurant — a big plus.I guess my issue is that I expected a warmer welcome at a small, family run (as I understand it) hotel. It’s not that the front desk person was unpleasant, but I didn’t feel anything that constitutes a warm welcome. That is surprising, because at a small independent hotel I expect an experience that doesn’t make me feel like just another guest, but a welcome that paves the way to many future stays.I am going to be back again for a couple of nights in two weeks and I hope that my experience will make me want to return again.

Most important: beds are very good.The room is quiet because of the location of the hotel on 13th. However, the elevator is very noisy so I went to buy a set of earplugs on 6th Av. That solved the problem adequately. The room is dark and cool, my priorities 3 and 4.Working space at the desk is small, but other, more expensive rooms will probably be a bit more convenient: at the front of the hotel there are 4 rooms and at the back there are 3 on the same width of the building.Finally, the room was clean but just enough. A bit more attention could be given to that.

Our stay at the Walker was perfect. The art deco style and cozy atmosphere made it a great place in which to return after a day in the city. Beautiful detail inside and out, an extremely helpful staff and a warm, welcoming lobby for working, chatting or listening to the live musicians they bring in. We enjoyed an incredible view of the city from our small balcony and the bath tub was a luxurious treat! I'll definitely make this my go-to hotel when traveling to NYC,

This is just an amazing find. What a welcoming, cozy lobby to walk into. Just a fabulous job recreating the art deco cafe society feel. The rooms are immaculate and beautiful and just a perfect renovation of the original art deco era. The rooms are very quiet as well. The beds are appointed with wonderful mattresses and linens. Even the plumbing fixtures are top notch. I do not even consider staying anyplace else when I'm in NYC. the staff could not be friendlier!

I had the pleasure of staying here and meeting an exceptional group of employees. I’d like to personally thank Anna, Liza, Abner and Marc for providing exceptional service during check in and through my stay. Can’t wait to return!

The Walker Hotel is in a great location-- convenient to subway and other transportation, and in the lovely Greenwich Village/ Chelsea area, on a relatively quiet street. Nice areas to walk, and great Italian and other restaurants within blocks. Also a Starbucks around the corner on 14th Street, which was very convenient. The rooms are small (in NYC I think all are, though). The staff was very polite, competent and helpful. From the concierge who helped so much with tickets, etc. to the Bellman and those at the desk who helped us know which subways to take, I couldn't have asked for better. Great to be so close to subway, which makes the city so accessible without having to stay in the busier/ noisier areas. Also, nice restaurant and bar. I have stayed here two trips for multiple days each, and will stay here again next time.

I’m shocked this hotel is rated so highly. I recently stayed here and was not impressed. The room was booked for three people, but the room was not big enough for three people. The beds were just slightly wider than twin beds and super uncomfortable to sleep with two people in one bed. There was no space for luggage and only one small closet with four hangers and three tiny drawers. While we were there, our shower broke and the fire alarm went off in the middle of the night—false alarm. The housekeeping service was hard to figure out, sometimes they came, sometimes they didn’t. Even when you posted the sign on the door, it was hit or miss, no rhyme or reason. I will say that the staff was super friendly and welcoming. No matter who you spoke to in the hotel or restaurant, the hospitality was amazing. The other thing I loved is that they left cookies for you daily which were made daily in the restaurant. We loved them so much, we tried to purchase some. We requested a specific kind, they charged me for it, then brought out a plate of completely different cookies, stating they didn’t have them anymore. That night at dinner, the lady recognized me and said that they were making the ones we wanted and would bring them to our room the next day. The cookies showed up, but were again the wrong ones. Both plates of cookies were thrown out. I would not recommend this hotel and won’t be returning. The service was friendly, but that’s not enough for me, I need a quality hotel as well.

The outside of the hotel is charming. 13th street has a bevy of restaurants to choose from. Its an easy walk to the subway. The lobby and bar are adorable and make you feel like you are in the "old" Greenwich Village. The largest CON is my fault and my choice. I chose the budget/value of a Grove Queen room for my husband and me. Way too small--felt like I was at a Four Points Sheraton. Beds were so low they were practically on the floor. Also, the air conditioning vent is EXTREMELY loud. If you like to sleep with white noise, then you will be fine. The staff is indifferent. We were handed the previous guests private information upon check in. Then there was the random hotel guest who greeted us at the check-in counter stating "there is a thief on the loose in the hotel...you should switch hotels". The hotel staff did not address these comments. It was just an....odd stay. That being said, we are frequent NYC hotel guests. Our favorite hotel in Greenwich Village is The Marlton. Same price point; same old world vibe---but done in a much more polished way. If you insist on staying at The Walker---upgrade your room and do NOT choose a Grove Queen.

Wonderful boutique hotel. Professional, classy, great amenities, very comfortable, friendly and accommodating staff. Good location. Delicious food. Would definitely stay here again. Excellent service, very clean and had very comfortable sleep..Perfect for my needs.

We had a great experience at the Walker Hotel. The employees are wonderful and gave us great service. Extremely helpful and friendly. Location was perfect with easy access to restaurants and stores. We will definitely stay again.

Though the room was small, it was perfectly arranged to create a cozy, comfortable stay. The entire staff are friendly, courteous and very accommodating. Having a very good restaurant on site was a bonus!

Everything you want in a boutique hotel, defines the Walker.Charming,sophisticated and oh so welcoming. The staff is friendly & helpful. The rooms are small but have everything you could need.The beds are incredibly comfortable. As if this wasn't enough. A wonderful lounge area & a very popular restaurant .

We LOVED our stay at the Walker Hotel. AMAZING!! My best friend & I were celebrating our 40th birthdays in the city. From the minute we walked in the door, we were in love! The hotel is such a timeless place. You can’t even tell it’s a hotel from the outside. In fact, we almost passed it when we walked by! Just a fancy building with gorgeous doors and beautiful landscaping. The staff was super helpful, so courteous & very friendly!! I love good customer service. It’s hard to find anymore these days, so we were very impressed. They offered us chilled bottles of water upon arrival. Stored our bags for us while we went exploring before our room was ready. Always greeted us with a smile and asked how we were doing. The lobby is so pretty. A grand staircase leads you down into a cozy sitting area with a fireplace. At night they had live music and a cute restaurant called Society Cafe where you could get craft cocktails. The rooms are the perfect size, not too big, not too small. Beds are super comfy!! We did have an issue with the AC in our room, but the manager Lisa moved us without any hesitation and Mark, the concierge, was SO nice & helpful with our move. We would definitely stay here again. Without hesitation. The Greenwich Village area is so quaint, that’s why we love it there. So many cute shops and restaurants surround the hotel. I would highly recommend a stay here!!! You won’t be disappointed!!

I booked a last minute trip to NYC and had few options between crazy expensive rooms and north of 14th street...where I rarely venture. I saw an ad for The Walker and took a chance. Boy, am I glad I did. It was a joy. The lobby is warm and inviting, the staff was incredible and the restaurant was a delight. It might have quickly replaced my favorite hotel in the city.

Great energy, good service and a friendly staff in a well-designed and authentic environment. A good place to hide from the craziness of the city. I have been looking for a home base in NYC and The Walker may be it!

Located on a hidden, quiet street one block from 14th St. A tranquil oasis in a frantic city. I find this hotel ideally situated in the city - certainly central to my interests. Excellent staff, excellent facilities, adorable bartender! I can’t wait to return.

Ideally located close to Union Square with shops/restaurants/subway nearby, a very nice and quiet hideaway from all this bustle after a long day exploring the city. I should specifically mention the fast and free WiFi connection and the very friendly staff.

We stayed at the Walker for a long weekend in late June. Our room on the 17th floor was a great size for Manhattan, had a huge bathroom, and also came with a small outside terrace where we sat and had drinks in the afternoon. We had an amazing view of the Empire State Building! The decor is a 1920s Art Deco style that is polished without being overbearing. I thought the rotary phone was a cute touch. The closet is a little small for two people travelling; a bit more space to store clothes would have been nice. The staff at the hotel were lovely, from housekeeping, through the waitstaff, to reception were all friendly and helpful. This was a relaxing and fun base to stay in for a weekend in New York City. The Greenwich Village location is super convenient for sightseeing, shopping, and work.

The hotel does fill a 'location void' for decent hotels. We wished it did a better job. The good points: rooms have been updated; complimentary water; nice robe and slippers; built in AC, Bigelow bath amenities. Offsetting points: housekeeping, very small armoire with jacket height rod, small safe, rotary dial phone (really), LCD TV does not rotate, older style bathroom with one small shelf over toilet, not over friendly staff. One night room was not cleaned by 4pm; when we called again at 4:30pm the front desk was impatient with us. Another day, toilet paper not refreshed. Sidewalk signage suggests LGBT friendly. We had hoped to find a nice hotel in this area, but we will keep looking.

This was a second visit to the hotel having stayed in 2015. Deco theme and hotel vibe are very charming. Room was reasonably spacious and our room afforded a great view. Housekeeping seemed lacking in comparison to our previous visit - intermittent replacement of bathroom amenities, water only sometimes replaced etc. Breakfast choice limited. A good hotel & stay, for understandably high NYC prices service could be sharper.

Loved this place. Had a flood in my apartment and had to book this last minute. Staff was very sweet and there was complimentary water and 2 drinks at bar. The beds were so comfortable and bath products were great. Liked the cozy room. Wet much

Room 1607 has view of Empire State Bldg. Great for the July 4th week. But no coffee maker or small frig in the room....we were here 4 yrs. ago and they had coffee maker. also July 2-5,was heat wave in NYC and they HAD A FIREPLACE GOING...REALLY.... instead, what about ice cold water with lemons or oranges floating in it....Had to ask for more hair shampoo and conditioner (not provided when we got there) also had to ask for stationery and pen to make notes (not provided, but available when asked for)....playing it cheap with these.....they have a new chef....very limited bar and lunch menu. FORGET THE SALADS. ordered kale salad, which turned out to be mostly kale with boxed croutons....very boring, cheaply made and overpriced...restaurant was empty...Kitchen for bar closes early...eat somewhere else and get a salad at "To Go"...they make a better one. would have appreciated small frig to keep vodka or water cold..this is a necessity...will not be returning..better deals at VBO.

Pro's:- location is fantastic, quiet street a few blocks from great subway stations, a few longer blocks from Greenwich Village, Union Square, etc. It's the ideal neighborhood to visit Manhattan, really.- hotel looks great, employees are courteous and helpful- room is nice, well insulated from street noise , well insulated from other rooms- bathroom is nice, bath products are great- wifi is very goodCon's:- a little pricey for what you get- rooms are small and can use a new mattress (mine was a bit saggy), a coffee maker, and a fridge.- hallways are narrow/tight so hallway conversations and slamming doors are loudThat being said, I think this hotel is going to be my go-to place the next time I come.

Pleasant hotel, nice helpful staff, - for the room rate it would have been a benefit to have had either a fridge or a kettle, or preferably both, I was quite surprised they didn't have either, maybe I'm just used to European hotels. Good sized room, great location, quiet but easily accessible for everywhere. We only had breakfast in the restaurant, but it seemed really overpriced, so we didn't try any other meals there. Overall it was a very pleasant place to stay, and a change from the 'corporate' hotels.

I just finished a weekend visit at the Walker Hotel with my teenage son, his friend and his friend's mom. We booked two rooms. I have visited NYC 4 times and this is my favorite location. The neighborhood felt very safe. We even let the teenage boys roam around on their own. There were several places to eat within a few blocks and lots of shopping. The actual street it was on was very quiet. There is a subway station very close and it is centrally located in NYC.The staff was friendly and helpful. The lobby was beautiful. There are stairs going down when you first come in, so keep that in mind if you have a disability. The floors are marble and become slick when wet.The room was small, but all NYC rooms are. It was decorated in a beautiful art deco style. We were on the 13th floor and had a nice view of the city. The room was clean and the beds and pillows were comfy. There is a very tiny closet and a little bench that you can put your suitcase on, but not much room anywhere else. The bathroom has one of those showers that sprays you in the face as soon as you turn it on. There isn't much counter space for your makeup,etc. The toiletries supplied were shampoo, conditioner, shower gel, soap, cotton balls, shower cap and makeup remover towelettes. Other than the shampoo and conditioner, nothing was replaced after the first night, but I'm sure they would have if I had asked. The water pressure in the shower was GREAT. The room was quiet. The a/c was very loud, but maybe that drowned out other noises. I occasionally heard doors slamming, but not often. I didn't hear any street noise other than when we opened the window (which only opens a crack by the way). There were no USB charging plugs in the room and nowtenough regular plugs by the nightstand. I would recommend they add a little more. Also, the room is really dark overall including the bathroom. A lighted makeup mirror would be a nice additon.The restaurant downstairs was nice but expensive. I got a glass of house chardonnay that was $20 and we spent about $130 on breakfast for the 4 of us one day.There is a nice Italian restaurant across the street named Da Andrea that I would highly recommend. It was adorable and priced reasonably.

What can I say? The Walker Hotel is fantastic and the staff is outstanding! From the bartender to the bellman, everyone was extremely helpful and attentive. A special shoutout to Marcus the concierge who made me feel like a VIP.Of course the room is small as is expected in New York, but the walk-in shower is really nice and the complimentary bottled (glass) water was a great touch. The cozy lobby lounge allowed me space to work outside the confines of my room. The gym is tiny, but had weights and cardio machines so adequate. Again, lots of complimentary bottled water there as well.I requested a top floor and the front desk staff said it may take longer than the expected check-in time but promised to call me when it was ready, which they did, well ahead of posted check-in time. The view from the 17th floor was of the Freedom Tower in the distance and rooftop gardens close by. It was relatively quiet at night. I was able to walk to restaurants, coffee, the world famous Blue Note Jazz Club and Washington Square Park and NYU were only five blocks away. From the hotel I was able to walk to Hudson River Park and the Highline. I’ve already recommended the hotel to a New Yorker who has quite a few guests come to visit. I hope I have more travels to New York soon so I can stay at the Walker again.

I spent four days at The Walker Hotel and honestly could find nothing that was not excellent! The service, the room, the food and the staff were relatively PERFECT!!! I loved my stay and highly recommend The Walker in Greenwich Village It is a JEWEL!!!!

I was here on business and I would not come back, especially on my own money since the quality is far below what is expected given the price and 4 star rating. The room is dark and had many unconvenient flaws, in particular in the restroom. The shower in the room I stayed in is separated from the rest of the bathroom only by a short curtain and the water is really pressurised, so even if you are careful you will soak the whole room. The water stagnates on the floor because the drain is badly fitted, with a tall edge that stops water from flowing in. There are stains in the sink, which also wobbles, signs of water damage on the ceilings just to name a few. The staff wasn’t welcoming, and neither very professional in dealing with an issue in the kitchen that delayed our breakfast. The food quality is also disappointing.
